snippet: Companies are creating words and symbols that are gaining recognition on the Web and followers. Examples include the “like” of Facebook and the abbreviation LOL (laugh out loud).
abstract: Jenna Wortham Bits column comments on the language of technology and social networking; observes that companies are creating words and symbols that are gaining recognition, including the 'like' of Facebook and the abbreviation LOL (laugh out loud); notes that LOL and OMG are included in the Oxford English Dictionary. Drawing (M)/
lead_paragraph: WHEN a friend recently asked for advice about using social media, I excitedly embarked on a description of my daily routine -- checking in on Foursquare to share my whereabouts with friends, posting tweets to Twitter, sharing screenshots from the latest ''Mad Men'' episode on Tumblr, and skimming through the stylized images on Instagram. He shook his head. It wasn't just that he wasn't familiar with the microblogging sites I regularly use. ''You're speaking another language,'' he said.

headline.main: Coining Terminology for Life on the Web
